title: What is the worst Beatles album (not including compilation or greatest hits albums, of course)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Fun question — thanks for the A2A. It highlights an old split in Beatles fans, reflected by their first two “greatest hits” albums. In high school my friend and I were fans, but he liked the Red album (their earlier stuff, through Rubber Soul if I recall), and I liked the Blue album (the later stuff). While I have come to appreciate the earlier music, I still think this split is useful, and I think there must be two answers to your question. I don’t know the first four albums well enough to say one is the worst, but I expect a lot of people would pick one of them (not later — Rubber Soul, Hard Day’s Night or Revolver — though!). Whichever that is, call it the Worst Red Album. I would call Let It Be the Worst Blue Album. It has some really good songs on it, but then, they didn’t make many bad ones. It has a mish-mash feeling to me, partly because they were off doing their own thing (which did not ruin the white album), but probably also because they brought in a new producer for (I think) the first time. Phil Spector has produced some awesome music, but I don’t think he and the Beatles ever figured out how to mesh their very distinct visions. Spector was famous for spending ages in the studio, and I don’t think the Beatles wanted to spend much more time with one another, let alone a new visionary/megalomaniac. [Trivia: Let It Be is not the last album they made. They pulled together to make Abbey Road before they called it quits, but legal problems (I think around the related movie) held Let It Be up.] I like Ian’s answer (Pete Best’s “Best of the Beatles”) — never knew about that one :).

Help! is the worst real Beatles album for me, if I don’t count Yellow Submarine, which is much, much, much worse (though it has a pair of excellent songs.) It’s kind of half a compilation or…whatever it is, Yellow Submarine’s a mess. While songs like “Ticket to Ride”, Help!” “Yesterday” and “I’ve Just Seen a Face” are nothing short of sublime, and “You’re Going to Lose that Girl” is an all right throwback, the rest of the songs are mediocre at best and dull and flat at worst. You’ve also got “You’ve Got to Hide Your Love Away”, a cutesy Dylan pastiche saved only by the amazing vocal. Otherwise, you have some very dull McCartney rockers (“The Night Before” and “Another Girl”); a pair of flat listless Harrison pop songs (“You Like Me Too Much” seems particularly phoned in) a boring country rock song (“Act Naturally”— they would do the same sort of thing much better on Rubber Soul’s “What Goes On") an embarrasingly silly pop song “Tell Me What You See.” And an OK Roy Orbison impersonation in “It’s Only Love.” And then “Dizzy Miss Lizzy” which is just — I mean, yes, it rocks, but at that point the Lennon’s Larry Williams thing was getting old. The vocal is ridiculously inappropriate and “hard rock”; I feel that all the sex inherent in the song has been shouted out of it — “Slow Down” it ain’t. As always with the Beatles, the songs I’m not keen on all have some good things going for them: McCartney’s gnarly guitar in “Another Girl", the enthusiasm of “The Night Before”, the drumming and rhythm guitar of “I Need You.” But I think it would have been a far greater better album had they included the B-sides of the era (especially “I’m Down”) and shaved a couple of songs off. Clearly a year and a half of mega-fame, a massive global tour, the filming of two movies and the writing and recording of three albums was wearing them thin. They bounced back with Rubber Soul at the very end of that year.

Being in the UK some of the earlier albums had different listings to those released in the US, but out of the UK releases the worst one was Beatles For Sale just edging out Yellow Submarine. This is because in my opinion the latter is only half a Beatles album with exception of the title they weren’t bad. Back to Beatles For Sale, all of the cover versions with may be the exception of Rock n Roll Music, could be dropped. They are some of their poorer renditions they made. That leaves 9 out of 14 tracks. The outstanding track is “Eight Days A Week” although not a single release in the UK. I quite like “No Reply” and “I’m A Loser” but that’s probably as my mum bought the first EP with these tracks on and played it to death. Parlophone released 2 EP’s from this album, the expression flogging a dead horse comes to mind. Of the rest I am pushed to recall what they are like apart from “I’ll Follow The Sun”, quite a pleasant track, and “Baby’s In Black”, which sounds like it should have been on “With The Beatles”, but its okay. Just played the other songs just in case I missed any gems.The only I played all the way through was “What You’re Doing”, okay but hardly memorable. Sometimes the Beatles would not include their single releases onto albums as they felt that the album was strong enough. A bad call in this case where “I Feel Fine” and the B side “She’s A Woman” would have enhanced it considerably.

This is a very easy question. There is only one possible answer. The “worst” Beatles album is clearly Yellow Submarine, not because anything on it is necessarily artistically bad, but because it offers only four previously unreleased Beatles songs—all of them leftovers. One of these leftovers (“Hey Bulldog”) is a minor masterpiece, of course, but as a whole, the album is the only one that doesn’t give terrific value for money. Lance’s answer argues that it doesn’t count, and I suppose you can argue that if you like, but it totally does. It’s one of the basic discs you need to complete their core catalog.

Writing purely from a subjective point of view ,I'd say The White Album.I really don't see what is the big deal with it.After 3 fabulous experimental albums they came up with this mainstream pretentious collection of jargon which obviously was a nod to their early albums without losing the experimental feel.The Result?An album with songs that have no meaning not to mention it's associations with the Mansion Family crimes and an album that doesn't even sound half as good as Sgt Peppers or Revolver.

The Beatles are always innovative, almost no matter what they’re playing. They were increasing innovative even when they were in Hamburg, always wanting to learn more more more new songs! That being said, the album with the least number of great originals is probably Beatles for sale. In my view, McCartney’s “I’ll Follow The Sun” is the best song on that album. At that time, they had gained fame so fast and toured so much, they hadn’t had much time to do enough writing to put out an album. They sure fixed that problem fast!

Best of the Beatles A sleazy trick if ever there was, former Beatles drummer Pete Best released an album with his new quintet titled "Best of the Beatles" (get it?). Eager fans expecting a compilation of Beatles' hits instead found themselves subjected to Pete Best original tunes such as "Shimmy Like My Sister Kate" and "She's Allright[sic]".

Probably “Please Please Me”, the debut album which is still pretty painful to listen. Beatles hadn`t found their face yet. They sound corny, girly and a way too sweet. But for a little surprise, the next, “With”, is totally different album and shows the real The Beatles: square, rough, innovative, idiosyncratic band.

Yellow Submarine, probably, even though that has a few great songs on it as well. There are some repeats from previous albums on it, and the musical scored (Sea of Holes, Sea of Time, et cetera) take the speed out of it a bit. But as others have stated, ‘worst Beatles album’ is a bit of an oxymoron.
The Beatles never made a bad album. Most would say Let It Be was their weakest, but I prefer listening to that one rather than Beatles For Sale.

Thanks for the A2A. For artwork, Yellow Submarine. Only because it is very difficult to follow after artwork as sophisticated as Sgt. Pepper (not the inside; that was for the Beatles fans). For the music, song order, etc.? I have no idea. I find it difficult to not like any of their music. Best regards!
